sen.j: 官人（かんにん、かんじん、つかさびと）とは官吏・役人を指す言葉。
sen.e: Kannin (also known as Kanjin, Tsukasabito) means an official and a civil servant.
Kannin (also known as Kanjin, Tsukasabito) means an official and a civil servant.
Kannin (also known as Kanjin, Tsukasabito) means an official and a civil servant.

sen.j: 律令制では諸司の主典以上六位以下、平安時代には判官以下、特に近衛府の将監以下の官吏を指した。
sen.e: Especially in the ritsuryo system, Kannin meant the official at the rank of Sakan of Tsukasa (also known as Shi) or above and the court rank of Sixth Rank,

In the ritsuryo system, Kannin meant officials at the rank of Sakan of Tsukasa (also known as Shi) or above and the court rank of Sixth Rank or below, and in the Heian period, it meant officials at the rank of Jo or below, specifically lieutenant of Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards) or under.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れがあります。訳漏れ部分の追加と表現の見直し。
sen.e: In the ritsuryo system, Kannin meant officials at the rank of Sakan of Tsukasa (also known as Shi) or above and the court rank of Sixth Rank or below, and in the Heian period, it meant officials at the rank of Jo or below, specifically lieutenant of Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards) or under.

sen.j: 官人とは狭義では郡司を除く官位相当のある四等官または品官の官職についている官吏のことをいい､広義では郡司や官位相当のない使部・伴部・舎人なども含めて総称される。
sen.e: In a narrow sense, Kannin means the officials of Shitokan and the officials at the government posts of Honkan, both of which had corresponding court ranks, except for Gunji; and in a broad sense, Kannin collectively means the officials including Gunji, and Tukaibe, Tomobe, and Toneri, all of which did not have corresponding court ranks.

In a narrow sense, Kannin means the officials of Shitokan and the officials at the government posts of Honkan, both of which had corresponding court ranks, except for Gunji; and in a broad sense, Kannin collectively means the officials including Gunji and officials without corresponding court ranks such as Tukaibe, Tomobe, and Toneri.
sen.cmt: 後半部分の表現の見直し
sen.e: In a narrow sense, Kannin means the officials of Shitokan and the officials at the government posts of Honkan, both of which had corresponding court ranks, except for Gunji; and in a broad sense, Kannin collectively means the officials including Gunji and officials without corresponding court ranks such as Tukaibe, Tomobe, and Toneri.

sen.j: その中でも従五位下（五位）以上のものを貴族と呼称してそれ以下の位階に属する者のみを官人と称する場合もある。
sen.e: In some cases, among the above definition, those at Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade (Fifth Rank) or above may be called the nobles and only those below that court rank may be called Kannin.
In some cases, among the above definition, those at Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade (Fifth Rank) or above may be called the nobles and only those below that court rank may be called Kannin.
In some cases, among the above definition, those at Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade (Fifth Rank) or above may be called the nobles and only those below that court rank may be called Kannin.

sen.j: この場合、五位以上でも散位の場合は四等官・品官の地位にいないため、官人に准じて扱われる場合もある。
sen.e: In that case, as Sanni did not hold the posts of Shitokan or Honkan even they were at Fifth Rank or above, they were sometimes treated correspondingly as Kanjin.
In that case, as Sanni did not hold the posts of Shitokan or Honkan even when they were at Fifth Rank or above, they were sometimes treated accordingly as Kanjin.
In that case, as Sanni did not hold the posts of Shitokan or Honkan even when they were at Fifth Rank or above, they were sometimes treated accordingly as Kanjin.

sen.j: 八位以上の官人には租庸調・庸・雑徭が免除され､刑罰の上でも優遇された。
sen.e: Kannin at Eighth Rank or above were exempted from Soyocho, Yo, and Zoyo, and treated favorably in punishment.
Kannin at Eighth Rank or above were exempted from Soyocho, Yo, and Zoyo, and treated favorably in punishment.
Kannin at Eighth Rank or above were exempted from Soyocho, Yo, and Zoyo, and treated favorably in punishment.

sen.j: 五位以上には親族に位階を賜る蔭位の特典や田地の下賜などがあり､さらに官位が昇るにつれて特典が大きくなった。
sen.e: Kannin at Fifth Rank or above had privileges of Onni to receive the court rank for their family members, and of receiving paddy fields, and the like; and those at the higher court ranks had the bigger privileges.

Kannin at Fifth Rank or above had privileges of Onni to receive court ranks for their family members, and of receiving paddy fields and the like; and those at higher court ranks had bigger privileges.

Kannin at Fifth Rank or above had privileges of Onni to receive court ranks for their family members, and of receiving paddy fields and the like; and those at higher court ranks had bigger privileges.

sen.j: またこれとは別に上級官職にも同じような特典があった。
sen.e: Apart from them, the high-ranking government post holders also had the similar privileges.
Apart from them, high-ranking government post holders also had similar privileges.
Apart from them, high-ranking government post holders also had similar privileges.

sen.j: 初位以下の官人にも税制上一定の優遇がなされた。
sen.e: Also Kannin at Initial Rank or below were treated favorably in taxation to some extent.
Also Kannin at Initial Rank or below were treated favorably in taxation to some extent.
Also Kannin at Initial Rank or below were treated favorably in taxation to some extent.

sen.j: 武官とは帯刀する官人のことで具体的には軍事機関である衛府や馬寮､兵庫の職員､軍団の幹部､及び弾正台の巡察弾正などを指した。
sen.e: Bukan was Kannin who bore swords, specifically an officer at the military organizations like Efu, Meryo, and Tsuwamonogura, a leading officer of an army, and an officer Junsatsudanjo at Danjodai.

Bukan was Kannin who bore swords, specifically an officer at the military organizations such as Efu, Meryo, and Tsuwamonogura, a leading officer of an army, and Junsatsudanjo (a patrolling officer) at Danjodai.
sen.cmt: like をsuch as に変更、an officer Junsatsudanjo をJunsatsudanjo (a patrolling officer)に変更
sen.e: Bukan was Kannin who bore swords, specifically an officer at the military organizations such as Efu, Meryo, and Tsuwamonogura, a leading officer of an army, and Junsatsudanjo (a patrolling officer) at Danjodai.

sen.j: 文官はそれ以外の一般官人のことをいう。
sen.e: Bunkan was the civil servant other than Bukan.
Bunkan was the civil servant other than Bukan.
Bunkan was the civil servant other than Bukan.

sen.j: ただし､大宰府の職員や内舎人など帯刀する官人は武官ではなく文官として扱われた。
sen.e: Only Kannin at Dazaifu and Udoneri, who bore swords, were treated as Bunkan, not Bunkan.
Only Kannin at Dazaifu and Udoneri, who bore swords, were treated as Bunkan, not Bunkan.
Only Kannin at Dazaifu and Udoneri, who bore swords, were treated as Bunkan, not Bunkan.

sen.j: 武官の人事は兵部省が文官の人事は式部省が行った。
sen.e: Personnel affairs of Bunkan was undertook by Hyobusho and personnel affairs of Bukan was undertook by Shikibusho.
Personnel affairs of Bunkan was undertaken by Hyobusho and personnel affairs of Bukan was undertaken by Shikibusho.
Personnel affairs of Bunkan was undertaken by Hyobusho and personnel affairs of Bukan was undertaken by Shikibusho.

sen.j: 京官（きょうかん）は内官ともいい中央官庁に勤務する官人を称し､外官（げかん）とは地方官のことをいう。
sen.e: Kyokan was also called Naikan, meaning Kannin who worked at the national government, and Gekan meant Kannin who worked at local governments.
Kyokan was also called Naikan, meaning Kannin who worked at the national government, and Gekan meant Kannin who worked at local governments.
Kyokan was also called Naikan, meaning Kannin who worked at the national government, and Gekan meant Kannin who worked at local governments.

sen.j: ただし､京において政務を行う京職・摂津職の官人は京官扱いであった。
sen.e: Kannin at Kyoshiki and Settsushiki who attended to government affairs in Kyoto were exceptionally treated as Kyokan.
Kannin at Kyoshiki and Settsushiki who attended to government affairs in Kyoto were exceptionally treated as Kyokan.
Kannin at Kyoshiki and Settsushiki who attended to government affairs in Kyoto were exceptionally treated as Kyokan.

sen.j: 職事（しきじ）とは職務を持つ官人をいい､散位（さんに・さんい）とは職務を持たない官人､つまり位階だけしか持っていない者のこと。
sen.e: Shikiji was Kannin who had duties, whereas Sanni (also known as Sani) was Kannin who did not have duties, i.e., who only had the court ranks.
Shikiji was Kannin who had duties, whereas Sanni (also known as Sani) was Kannin who did not have duties, i.e., who only had the court ranks.
Shikiji was Kannin who had duties, whereas Sanni (also known as Sani) was Kannin who did not have duties, i.e., who only had the court ranks.

sen.j: 散位はほとんどが退職官人で京内の者と地方の五位以上の者は散位寮に常勤し､それ以外の者は各国府に交替勤務した。
sen.e: The most of Sanni were retired Kannin; those at Fifth Rank or above and lived in Kyoto and local provinces held full-time positions in Sanniryo, and the others alternatively worked at Kokufu.

Most of Sanni were retired Kannin; those who lived in Kyoto and those who were at Fifth Rank or above and lived in local provinces held full-time positions in Sanniryo, and the others alternately worked at respective Kokufu.

Most of Sanni were retired Kannin; those who lived in Kyoto and those who were at Fifth Rank or above and lived in local provinces held full-time positions in Sanniryo, and the others alternately worked at respective Kokufu.

sen.j: 武官・文官､京官・外官の区分がありこのうち武官（武散位）については兵部省が取り扱ったとも言われている。
sen.e: They were classified into Bunkan, Bukan, Kyokan, and Gekan, and it is considered that Bukan (Busanni) were under the supervision of Hyobusho.
They were classified into Bunkan, Bukan, Kyokan, and Gekan, and it is considered that Bukan (Busanni) were under the supervision of Hyobusho.
They were classified into Bunkan, Bukan, Kyokan, and Gekan, and it is considered that Bukan (Busanni) were under the supervision of Hyobusho.

tit.j: 勅任・奏任・判任・判補

sen.j: 勅任（ちょくにん）は天皇の詔勅（命令）により任命される官。
sen.e: Chokunin was a post appointed by the imperial edict (order).
Chokunin was a post appointed by the imperial edict (order).
Chokunin was a post appointed by the imperial edict (order).

sen.j: 奏任（そうにん）は天皇に奏聞した上で任命される官。
sen.e: Sonin was a post appointed after reporting to the emperor.
Sonin was a post appointed after reporting to the emperor about the appointment.
Sonin was a post appointed after reporting to the emperor about the appointment.

sen.j: 判任（はんにん）は太政官の任命､判補（はんぽ）は式部省（一部は兵部省）の任命する官。
sen.e: Hannin was a post appointed by Daijokan, and Hanpo was a post appointed by Shikibusho, or Hyobusho in some cases.
Hannin was a post appointed by Daijokan, and Hanpo was a post appointed by Shikibusho, or Hyobusho in some cases.
Hannin was a post appointed by Daijokan, and Hanpo was a post appointed by Shikibusho, or Hyobusho in some cases.

sen.j: 式部判補ともいう。
sen.e: They may be called Shikibuhanpo.
They were also called Shikibuhanpo.
They were also called Shikibuhanpo.

sen.j: これらの名称は戦前の政府の勅任官・奏任官などに継承された。
sen.e: These names were handed down to Chokuninkan and Soninkan in the government before WWII.
These names were handed down to Chokuninkan and Soninkan in the government before WWII.
These names were handed down to Chokuninkan and Soninkan in the government before WWII.

sen.j: 男官は政治に関わる一般的な官人のこと。
sen.e: Dankan were general male Kannin who took in charge of politics.
Dankan were general male Kannin who took charge of politics.
sen.cmt: took in charge of --> took charge of
sen.e: Dankan were general male Kannin who took charge of politics.

sen.j: 女官は主に後宮にあって后妃の世話をした。
sen.e: Nyokan were female officials worked at Kokyu, the women's quarters of the Imperial Palace, and took care of empress and consorts.
Nyokan were female officials working mainly at Kokyu, the women's quarters of the Imperial Palace, and mainly took care of the empress.
sen.cmt: worked を working mainly に変更、and took care of empress and consorts を and took care of the empressに変更
sen.e: Nyokan were female officials working mainly at Kokyu, the women's quarters of the Imperial Palace, and mainly took care of the empress.

sen.j: 平安時代には後宮以外の御厨子所などにも女官が置かれた。
sen.e: During the Heian period, Nyokan were allocated to Mizushidokoro other than Kokyu.
In the Heian period, Nyokan were allocated in Mizushidokoro other than Kokyu.
sen.cmt: DuringをInに、allocated to をallocated inに変更
sen.e: In the Heian period, Nyokan were allocated in Mizushidokoro other than Kokyu.

sen.j: ここでは広義の官人および参考として地方からの労働者である仕丁（しちょう・じちょう）を掲げた。
sen.e: Kannin in the broad sense, and, for reference, Shicho (also known as Jicho), the workers from local provinces, are shown below.
Kannin in a broad sense, and, for reference, Shicho (also known as Jicho), workers from local provinces, are shown below.
sen.cmt: the broad sense --> a broad sense, the workers --> workers
sen.e: Kannin in a broad sense, and, for reference, Shicho (also known as Jicho), workers from local provinces, are shown below.

sen.j: 常勤する官人のこと。
sen.e: Kannin who held full-time positions.
Kannin who held full-time positions.
Kannin who held full-time positions.

sen.j: 内・外の区分がある。
sen.e: Chojo were divided into Naichojo and Gaichojo.
Chojo were divided into Naichojo and Gaichojo.
Chojo were divided into Naichojo and Gaichojo.

sen.j: 各官司の基本職員。
sen.e: Regular officials at respective offices.
Regular officials at respective offices.
Regular officials at respective offices.

sen.j: 長官（かみ）が決裁､次官（すけ）が補佐､判官（じょう）が監査・事務､主典（さかん）が文書起草を行う。
sen.e: Kami took charge of decision, Suke took charge of assistance, Jo took charge of audit and clerical work, and Sakan took charge of drafting of documents.
Kami took charge of decision, Suke took charge of assistance, Jo took charge of audit and clerical work, and Sakan took charge of drafting of documents.
Kami took charge of decision, Suke took charge of assistance, Jo took charge of audit and clerical work, and Sakan took charge of drafting of documents.

sen.j: ほんかんと読む。
sen.e: Pronounced Honkan.
Pronounced Honkan.
Pronounced Honkan.

sen.j: 四等官とは別系統にある専門職員。
sen.e: Technical expert civil servants who were in a different official system from Shitokan.
Civil servants as technical experts belonging to a different official system from Shitokan.
Civil servants as technical experts belonging to a different official system from Shitokan.

sen.j: 本来は職 (律令制)・寮 (律令制)・司として独立させるべきであるがそれには規模が小さいためこのような形態となった。
sen.e: The number of officials in this category was too small to have had them independent as Shiki, Tsukasa (also known as Ryo), or Tsukasa (also known as Shi), otherwise they should have been to.

They should have been independently established as Shiki, Ryo, and Tsukasa (also known as Shi), however, the number of officials in this category was too small to do so, as a result, Honkan was established.
sen.cmt: 「寮」の読みをRyoとした。Tsukasaとの併記では「司」と混同される恐れがあるための措置。その他表現の見直し。
sen.e: They should have been independently established as Shiki, Ryo, and Tsukasa (also known as Shi), however, the number of officials in this category was too small to do so, as a result, Honkan was established.

sen.j: 大学寮の博士や陰陽寮の陰陽師､刑部省の判事など。
sen.e: Honkan consisted of doctors at Daigakuryo, Onmyoji at Onmyoryo, judges at Gyoubusho, and the like.
Honkan consisted of doctors at Daigakuryo, Onmyoji at Onmyoryo, judges at Gyoubusho, and the like.
Honkan consisted of doctors at Daigakuryo, Onmyoji at Onmyoryo, judges at Gyoubusho, and the like.

sen.j: 四等官とは別系統にある技術職員。
sen.e: Technical officials who were in a different official system from Shitokan.
Technical officials who were in a different official system from Shitokan.
Technical officials who were in a different official system from Shitokan.

sen.j: 品官より官位が低く､また工業系官司に多く設置されている。
sen.e: Their court ranks were lower than those of Honkan, and the most of their duties were related with manufacturing industries.
Their court ranks were lower than those of Honkan, and most of their duties were related with manufacturing industries.
Their court ranks were lower than those of Honkan, and most of their duties were related with manufacturing industries.

sen.j: 伴部や品部などを統率している場合もある。
sen.e: Some of them took command of Tomobe or Shinabe.
Some of them took command of Tomobe or Shinabe.
Some of them took command of Tomobe or Shinabe.

sen.j: 図書寮の造筆手・造墨手や大蔵省の典履など。
sen.e: Saigi no Chojo included Zohitsushu and Zobokushu at Zushiryo, and Tenri at Okurasho.
Saigi no Chojo included Zohitsushu and Zobokushu at Zushiryo, and Tenri at Okurasho.
Saigi no Chojo included Zohitsushu and Zobokushu at Zushiryo, and Tenri at Okurasho.

sen.j: 天皇の個別命令（別勅）によって任用される。
sen.e: Becchoku no Chojo was appointed by the imperial individual order (becchoku).
Becchoku no Chojo was appointed by the imperial individual order (becchoku).
Becchoku no Chojo was appointed by the imperial individual order (becchoku).

sen.j: 詳しいことは不明であるが芸人などのことをいったらしい。
sen.e: Details about the officials are unknown, but it is supposed that performers were appointed.
Details about this kind of officials are unknown, but it is supposed that they were entertainers and the like.
Details about this kind of officials are unknown, but it is supposed that they were entertainers and the like.

sen.j: 交替勤務をする官人。
sen.e: Kannin at shiftwork.
Kannin to work in shifts.
Kannin to work in shifts.

sen.j: 広義には雑色人・散位・仕丁・蔭子・位子も含めた。
sen.e: In a broad sense, Banjo included Zoshikinin, Sanni, Shicho, Onshi, and Ishi.
In a broad sense, Banjo included Zoshikinin, Sanni, Shicho, Onshi, and Ishi.
In a broad sense, Banjo included Zoshikinin, Sanni, Shicho, Onshi, and Ishi.

sen.j: ぞうにんと読む。
sen.e: Pronounced Zonin.
Pronounced Zonin.
Pronounced Zonin.

sen.j: 個々の官司において下働きや事務などを行う下級官人。
sen.e: Low-ranking Kannin who served as underworkers and clerks at individual offices.
Low-ranking Kannin who served as underworkers and clerks at individual offices.
Low-ranking Kannin who served as underworkers and clerks at individual offices.

sen.j: 四等官・品官からなる職事や才伎長上などの上級官人に対する存在である。
sen.e: Zonin were opposite of Shikiji consisted of Shitokan and Honkan, and the high-ranking Kannin including Saigi no Chojo.
Zonin were opposite to Shikiji consisted of Shitokan and Honkan, and high-ranking Kannin including Saigi no Chojo.
Zonin were opposite to Shikiji consisted of Shitokan and Honkan, and high-ranking Kannin including Saigi no Chojo.

sen.j: 皇親や五位以上の従者である帳内・資人もこれに準じる。
sen.e: Chonai, the imperial kin, and Shijin, retainers at Fifth Rank or above, corresponded to Zonin.
Chonai, the imperial kin, and Shijin, retainers at Fifth Rank or above, corresponded to Zonin.
Chonai, the imperial kin, and Shijin, retainers at Fifth Rank or above, corresponded to Zonin.

sen.j: 式部省の判補によって採用されて交代で勤務する分番を採っており、官位相当はない。
sen.e: The officials were appointed by Hanpo at Shikibusho, worked on a shift system, and did not have corresponding court rank.
The officials were appointed by Hanpo at Shikibusho, worked on a shift system, and did not have a corresponding court rank.
sen.cmt: corresponding court rankに冠詞aを付与
sen.e: The officials were appointed by Hanpo at Shikibusho, worked on a shift system, and did not have a corresponding court rank.

sen.j: 特典として課役が免ぜられる。
sen.e: They had a privilege of being exempted from allocation of work.
They had a privilege of being exempted from Kaeki (distribution of assignments).
sen.cmt: 「課役」の訳に用語集の用語を使用
sen.e: They had a privilege of being exempted from Kaeki (distribution of assignments).

sen.j: 毎年上・中・下の3等で評価され、8年分の評価（ただし706年の格式で実際には6年分の評価で運用）に基づいて最大で3階相当分の叙位が行われた。
sen.e: They were annually rated using three-point scale of Jo, Chu, Ge, and were conferred on the ranks higher by up to three based on the rating for eight years (according to the law in 706, this rule was operated based on six years rating in fact.)

They were annually rated using the three-point scale of Jo, Chu, Ge, and were conferred on the ranks higher by up to three based on the rating of eight years (according to the law in 706, this rule was operated based on a six years rating in fact).
sen.cmt: three-point scale --> the three-point scale, on the rating for eight years --> on the rating of eight years,six years rating --> a six years rating
sen.e: They were annually rated using the three-point scale of Jo, Chu, Ge, and were conferred on the ranks higher by up to three based on the rating of eight years (according to the law in 706, this rule was operated based on a six years rating in fact).

sen.j: 以下のような種類がある。
sen.e: Zonin had subcategories as below.
Zonin had subcategories as below.
Zonin had subcategories as below.

sen.j: 史生（ししょう）
sen.e: Shisho
Shisho
Shisho

sen.j: 文書事務を行う。
sen.e: They were in charge of clerical work.
They were in charge of clerical work.
They were in charge of clerical work.

sen.j: もともとは太政官・神祇官や八省および主税寮・主計寮など一部の官司にしか置かれていなかったが､行政の煩雑化に伴って様々な官司へ増置された。
sen.e: Shisho were originally placed at some offices as Daijokan, Jingikan, the eight ministries, Shuzeiryo, and Shukeiryo; and as the administration became complicated, Shisho were additionally placed in other offices.

Shisho were originally placed in some offices such as Daijokan, Jingikan, the eight ministries, Shuzeiryo, and Shukeiryo; however, as the administration became complicated, Shisho were additionally placed in other offices.
sen.cmt: at some officeを in some officesに変更, asの前にsuch挿入、セミコロンの次のandをhoweverに変更。
sen.e: Shisho were originally placed in some offices such as Daijokan, Jingikan, the eight ministries, Shuzeiryo, and Shukeiryo; however, as the administration became complicated, Shisho were additionally placed in other offices.

sen.j: 書生（しょしょう）
sen.e: Shosho
Shosho
Shosho

sen.j: 文書の校正・清書を行う。
sen.e: They were in charge of proofreading and making fair copies.
They were in charge of proofreading and making fair copies.
They were in charge of proofreading and making fair copies.

sen.j: 平安時代に八省・大宰府に置かれて重要性が増した。
sen.e: During the Heian period, they were placed in the eight ministries and Dazaifu, and gained importance.
During the Heian period, they were placed in the eight ministries and Dazaifu, and gained importance.
During the Heian period, they were placed in the eight ministries and Dazaifu, and gained importance.

sen.j: －掌（－しょう）
sen.e: Sho
Sho
Sho

sen.j: 史生と使部の中間で使部に指示して雑務を行わせる。
sen.e: They worked between Shisho and Tsukaibe, ordering Tsukaibe to carry out miscellaneous business.
They worked between Shisho and Tsukaibe, ordering Tsukaibe to carry out miscellaneous business.
They worked between Shisho and Tsukaibe, ordering Tsukaibe to carry out miscellaneous business.

sen.j: 掌の前には各官司名が入り（官掌・省掌など）後には職・寮などにも多数設置された。
sen.e: Sho was suffixed onto the respective office names like Kansho, Shosho, and in the later ages, Sho were placed in a lot of offices of Shiki and Tsukasa (also known as Ryo.)
Sho was suffixed onto the respective office names like Kansho, Shosho, and in the later ages, Sho were placed in a lot of offices of Shiki and Ryo.
sen.cmt: 「寮」の読みをRyoとした。Tsukasaとの併記では「司」と混同される恐れがあるための措置です。
sen.e: Sho was suffixed onto the respective office names like Kansho, Shosho, and in the later ages, Sho were placed in a lot of offices of Shiki and Ryo.

sen.j: （職掌・寮掌など）
sen.e: (Shikisho, Ryosho, and the like)
(Shikisho, Ryosho, and the like)
(Shikisho, Ryosho, and the like)

sen.j: 使部（つかいべ・しぶ）
sen.e: Tsukaibe (also known as Shibu)
Tsukaibe (also known as Shibu)
Tsukaibe (also known as Shibu)

sen.j: 各官司の雑務にあたる官人。
sen.e: Kannin in charge of miscellaneous business of the respective offices.
Kannin in charge of miscellaneous business in the respective offices.
sen.cmt: of the respective offices --> in the respective offices
sen.e: Kannin in charge of miscellaneous business in the respective offices.

sen.j: 中央の全官司に設置された。
sen.e: Tukaibe were placed in all offices of the national government.
Tukaibe were placed in all offices of the national government.
Tukaibe were placed in all offices of the national government.

sen.j: もともとは六位以下の官人の子息を三等に分けた最下等が任用された。
sen.e: Tsukaibe were originally held by the lowest rank of the sons of Kannin at Sixth Rank or below divided into three ranks.
Sons of Kannin at Sixth Rank or below were classified into three ranks, by the lowest of which Tsukaibe were originally held.
Sons of Kannin at Sixth Rank or below were classified into three ranks, by the lowest of which Tsukaibe were originally held.

sen.j: ちなみに上等は大舎人､中等は兵衛である。
sen.e: The highest ranked sons were appointed Otoneri, and the middle ranked sons were appointed Hyoe.
The highest ranked sons were appointed Otoneri, and the middle ranked sons were appointed Hyoe.
The highest ranked sons were appointed Otoneri, and the middle ranked sons were appointed Hyoe.

sen.j: 舎人（とねり）
sen.e: Toneri
Toneri
Toneri

sen.j: 要人の雑務・護衛にあたった官人。
sen.e: Kannin who were in charge of miscellaneous business and guarding of very important persons.
Kannin who were in charge of miscellaneous business and guarding of very important persons.
Kannin who were in charge of miscellaneous business and guarding of very important persons.

sen.j: 内舎人・大舎人・中宮舎人・東宮舎人・斎宮舎人などがあり､なかでも内舎人は上級官人の子息が任用されて出世の足がかりとなった。
sen.e: Toneri included Udoneri, Otoneri, Togutoneri, Saigutoneri, and the like; among others, the sons of high-ranking Kannin were appointed Udoneri and used the post as their stepping-stone toward higher posts.

Toneri included Udoneri, Otoneri, Chugutoneri, Togutoneri, Saigutoneri, and the like; among them, the sons of high-ranking Kannin were appointed Udoneri and used the post as their stepping-stone toward higher posts.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れあり。「中宮舎人」の訳を追記。among othersを among themに変更
sen.e: Toneri included Udoneri, Otoneri, Chugutoneri, Togutoneri, Saigutoneri, and the like; among them, the sons of high-ranking Kannin were appointed Udoneri and used the post as their stepping-stone toward higher posts.

sen.j: 兵衛（ひょうえ）
sen.e: Hyoe
Hyoe
Hyoe

sen.j: 兵衛府に属した兵士。
sen.e: Soldiers who belonged to Hyoefu.
Soldiers who belonged to Hyoefu.
Soldiers who belonged to Hyoefu.

sen.j: 舎人の一種で天皇の近辺を警護した。
sen.e: They took charge of personal protection of the emperor as a kind of Toneri.
They took charge of personal protection of the emperor as a kind of Toneri.
They took charge of personal protection of the emperor as a kind of Toneri.

sen.j: 伴部（ともべ・とものみやつこ・ばんぶ）
sen.e: Tomobe (also known as Tomonomiyatsuko, Banbu)
Tomobe (also known as Tomonomiyatsuko, Banbu)
Tomobe (also known as Tomonomiyatsuko, Banbu)

sen.j: 令制以前の伴造の系統にあり､百済手部のようにほとんどは品部・雑戸を率いて現業特に工業部門を指揮した。
sen.e: Tomobe originated from Tomonomiyatsuko before the ritsuryo legal code system, and as Kudaratebito, most of them supervised especially the industrial branches at the work-site operations by heading Shinabe and Zakko.

Tomobe originated from Tomonomiyatsuko before the ritsuryo legal code system, and like Kudaratebito, most of them supervised especially the industrial branches at the work-site operations leading Shinabe and Zakko.
sen.cmt: as Kudaratebito --> like Kudaratebito, by heading --> leading
sen.e: Tomobe originated from Tomonomiyatsuko before the ritsuryo legal code system, and like Kudaratebito, most of them supervised especially the industrial branches at the work-site operations leading Shinabe and Zakko.

sen.j: また内礼司の主礼のように現業に携わらない例外もあった。
sen.e: As an exception, Shurai in Nairaishi were not engaged in the work-site operations.
As an exception, Shurai in Nairaishi were not engaged in work-site operation.
As an exception, Shurai in Nairaishi were not engaged in work-site operation.

sen.j: これらの多くは統廃合によって廃止されたり､内匠寮の圧迫によって衰退していった。
sen.e: Most of them were streamlined by merger and abolition or declined under the pressure of Naishoryo.
Most of them were streamlined by merger and abolition or declined under the pressure of Naishoryo.
Most of them were streamlined by merger and abolition or declined under the pressure of Naishoryo.

sen.j: 品部と雑戸の総称。
sen.e: Shinabe and Zakko were generically called Zoshikinin.
Shinabe and Zakko were generically called Zoshikinin.
Shinabe and Zakko were generically called Zoshikinin.

sen.j: 社会的地位は低く差別された。
sen.e: As their social standing was low, they were discriminated.
As their social standing was low, they were discriminated.
As their social standing was low, they were discriminated.

sen.j: 手工業部門に携わる者が多い。
sen.e: Most of them were engaged in handicraft manufacturing.
Most of them were engaged in handicraft manufacturing.
Most of them were engaged in handicraft manufacturing.

sen.j: 品部（しなべ・ともべ）
sen.e: Shinabe (also known as Tomobe)
Shinabe (also known as Tomobe)
Shinabe (also known as Tomobe)

sen.j: 一部大化の改新以前の品部の系譜を引く。
sen.e: Some Shinabe originated from Shinabe before Taika Reform.
Some Shinabe originated from Shinabe before the Taika Reforms.
sen.cmt: Taika Reform --> the Taika Reforms (京都プロジェクト用語集に依る）
sen.e: Some Shinabe originated from Shinabe before the Taika Reforms.

sen.j: 特殊技能を持った手工業者で図書寮の紙戸や大蔵省の狛戸などが代表的。
sen.e: Shinabe were handicraftsmen with special skills as represented by Kamiko of Zushiryo and Komahe of Okurasho.
Shinabe were handicraftsmen with special skills as represented by Kamiko of Zushiryo and Komahe of Okurasho.
Shinabe were handicraftsmen with special skills as represented by Kamiko of Zushiryo and Komahe of Okurasho.

sen.j: 律令制の崩壊と共に消滅した。
sen.e: Shinabe were extinct when the ritsuryo legal code system was collapsed.
Shinabe disappeared when the ritsuryo legal code system was collapsed.
Shinabe disappeared when the ritsuryo legal code system was collapsed.

sen.j: 雑戸（ざっこ）
sen.e: Zakko
Zakko
Zakko

sen.j: 軍事関係の特殊技術を持った者。
sen.e: Officials with special skills in military affairs.
Officials with special skills in military affairs.
Officials with special skills in military affairs.

sen.j: 五色の賤に準じられ差別された。
sen.e: They were discriminated correspondingly to Goshiki no sen.
They were ranked as Goshiki no sen (five lowly castes of the ritsuryo system) and discriminated correspondingly.
They were ranked as Goshiki no sen (five lowly castes of the ritsuryo system) and discriminated correspondingly.

sen.j: 造兵司の造工戸や主鷹司の鷹戸などがある。
sen.e: Examples of Zakko included Zoukobe of Zoheishi and Takabe of Shuyoshi.
Examples of Zakko included Zoukobe of Zoheishi and Takabe of Shuyoshi.
Examples of Zakko included Zoukobe of Zoheishi and Takabe of Shuyoshi.

sen.j: 律令制の崩壊と共に消滅した。
sen.e: Zakko were extinct when the ritsuryo legal code system was collapsed.
Zakko disappeared when the ritsuryo legal code system was collapsed.
Zakko disappeared when the ritsuryo legal code system was collapsed.

sen.j: しちょう・じちょうと読む。
sen.e: Pronounced Shicho and Jicho.
Pronounced Shicho or Jicho.
Pronounced Shicho or Jicho.

sen.j: 各里ごと二人ずつ徴発して一年交替で都に務めた。
sen.e: Two persons were commandeered from each village to serve every other year.
Two persons were commandeered from each village to serve in Kyoto for a year.
sen.cmt: to serve every other year --> to serve in Kyoto for a year
sen.e: Two persons were commandeered from each village to serve in Kyoto for a year.

sen.j: 食糧など一切は故郷の負担であったためかなりの負担となった。
sen.e: As provisions for them were saddled on their villages, Shicho were great burden for the villages.
As provisions for them were saddled on their villages, Shicho were a great burden for the villages.
As provisions for them were saddled on their villages, Shicho were a great burden for the villages.

sen.j: 直丁（じきちょう）
sen.e: Jikicho
Jikicho
Jikicho

sen.j: 各官司で労役を行った者。
sen.e: Kannin who served as laborer at the respective offices.
Kannin who served as a laborer at the respective offices.
Kannin who served as a laborer at the respective offices.

sen.j: 囚獄司以外の中央官司全てに配属された。
sen.e: They were allocated to all the offices of the national government except for Shugokushi.
They were allocated in all offices of the national government except for Shugokushi.
sen.cmt: to all the offices --> in all offices
sen.e: They were allocated in all offices of the national government except for Shugokushi.

sen.j: 駆使丁（くしちょう）
sen.e: Kushicho
Kushicho
Kushicho

sen.j: 大規模な現業部門に配属され労役を行った者。
sen.e: Kannin who were allocated to the large scale work-site operations and served as laborer.
Kannin who were allocated to large scale work-site operations and served as a laborer.
sen.cmt: the large scale work-site operationsから定冠詞theを除去、laborerに不定冠詞aを付与
sen.e: Kannin who were allocated to large scale work-site operations and served as a laborer.

sen.j: 木工寮・大膳職などにあった。
sen.e: They were allocated to Mokuryo and Daizenshiki.
They were allocated to Mokuryo and Daizenshiki.
They were allocated to Mokuryo and Daizenshiki.

sen.j: 厮丁（しちょう）
sen.e: Shicho
Shicho
Shicho

sen.j: 立丁（直丁・駆使丁）の食事や雑務を行った。
sen.e: Shicho were in charge of preparing meals and doing miscellaneous business for Rittei (Jikicho, Kushicho.)
Shicho were in charge of preparing meals and doing miscellaneous business for Rittei (Jikicho, Kushicho.)
Shicho were in charge of preparing meals and doing miscellaneous business for Rittei (Jikicho, Kushicho.)

sen.j: 匠丁（しょうてい）
sen.e: Shotei
Shotei
Shotei

sen.j: 主に飛騨国の各里から二人ずつ徴発した大工。
sen.e: Two persons were commandeered as carpenters from each village mainly of Hida province.
Two persons were commandeered as carpenters from each village mainly of Hida province.
Two persons were commandeered as carpenters from each village mainly of Hida province.

sen.j: 飛騨工（ひだのたくみ）ともいう。
sen.e: They were also called Hida no Takumi.
They were also called Hida no Takumi.
They were also called Hida no Takumi.

sen.j: 木工寮に配属された。
sen.e: They were allocated to Mokuryo.
They were allocated to Mokuryo.
They were allocated to Mokuryo.
